Total Hours Wasted

Letter from the Archivist

Priority: Low (always)
Posted: 2017-06-12 09:47:03 EST • Author: asharma@corpnet.internal • Dept: IT Support (dissolved)

Welcome to Bureaucratic Sincerity, the web's only archive dedicated to preserving the specific misery of the corporate intranet. If you've ever waited forty-five seconds for an HR policy PDF to load over the company network while your supervisor stood behind you asking if you'd "tried refreshing," this site is for you.

I spent eleven years maintaining portals that averaged six daily visitors, four of whom were bots. I watched three separate redesign committees form, meet bi-weekly for eight months, produce a PowerPoint deck titled "Intranet 2.0: A Vision," and then dissolve without changing a single pixel. These portals were where ambition went to render at 56kbps.

This archive exists because someone should remember. Not the technology — the feeling. The flicker of hope when the page started to load. The slow death when it didn't. We were all there. The portals were terrible. And somehow we kept showing up anyway.

— Anya Sharma, Archivist & Former Keeper of the Broken Links

Hall of Shame — Worst Intranet Specimens

Portal Redesign Proposals (2007)

Proposal A: "The Waterfall"

Submitted by: d.thornton@corpnet.internal • 04/11/2007

Replace all navigation with a single dropdown menu containing every page on the intranet. Alphabetically. Including archived pages from 1998. Users who can't find what they need "probably don't need it." Estimated completion: Q3 2007.

Status: Under Review (indefinitely)

Proposal B: "Fresh Eyes"

Submitted by: k.morrison@corpnet.internal • 04/18/2007

Redesign the entire portal using only animated GIFs and beveled buttons. Each department gets a custom cursor. HR requested a spinning globe. Kevin in Accounting wants flames. Nobody asked the users what they wanted because, and I quote, "users don't know what they want."

Status: Approved then abandoned

Proposal C: "Lean Portal"

Submitted by: a.sharma@corpnet.internal • 04/25/2007

Remove all broken links, update the phone directory, add a search bar that actually works. Total cost: $0 and two afternoons. Rejected for being "too simple to present to the steering committee." The steering committee met four more times. Nothing changed.

Status: Rejected (insufficient complexity)

The Death of the Corporate Intranet: A Timeline

2001
Flash splash pages become mandatory. Load times hit 2 minutes.
2003
SharePoint deployed. Nobody trained. Help desk tickets triple.
2005
"Intranet 2.0 Task Force" forms. Meetings begin. Nothing ships.
2007
Redesign proposals submitted. All three rejected. See above.
2009
IE6 still required. Chrome exists. We are not allowed to know.
2011
Someone discovers the portal runs on a server under Dave's desk.
2013
Flash officially deprecated. Our portal doesn't notice for 2 years.
2015
Slack adopted. The intranet dies. Nobody holds a funeral.
